isis.stitle: T 444E Diesel Engine Diagnostics (1997) - SECTION 2.2: HARD START/NO START DIAGNOSTICS - T 444E ENGINE - EST TOOL-FAULT CODES

svcprocinfo.para:
Refer to Table 2.7
for the EST Tool-Fault Codes test of the diagnostic form.

svcsubproc.title: Purpose
svcsubproc.para: To determine if the Electronic Control Module (ECM) has detected any fault conditions that would cause a hard or no start condition.

svcsubproc.title: Test Procedure

note.para: Turn all accessories and the ignition off, before connecting est tool to ATA diagnostic connector.

svcsubproc.para:
Connect the Electronic Service Tool (EST) to the American Trucking Association (ATA) diagnostic connector. The connector is located on the lower left kick panel ( Figure 2.6
) inside the cab. The screen of the reader should light up as soon as the tool is plugged in.

note.para: The ATA connector supplies power to operate the EST. The EST will automatically power up as soon as it is plugged into the ATA connector. The power cord is not required and is for use only when reading non-volatile memory.

figure.caption: Figure 2.6- Electronic Service Tool/ATA Connector Location

svcsubproc.para: Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position, but do not start the engine. This will allow the EST to receive data from the electronic control components on the truck. If no data is received, press "ENTER" to retry. The information received will be data showing the current status of the engine.

To access the fault codes press the "FUNC" key to switch to the main menu ( Figure 2.7
).
From the main menu select "ENGINE" by pressing the "←" key. This will cause the brackets to be placed around the "ENGINE"selection. Then press "ENTER".

From the next menu select " DIAGNOSTIC CODES". The selection will have the "↑ ↓" symbol on the screen. This means there are other selections available. By pressing the "↓" key the other selections will display on the screen. Press "↓" key until "DIAGNOSTIC CODES" appears on the screen ( Figure 2.8
).
Next press "ENTER".This causes the EST to enter the diagnostic codes section. From this point, diagnostic codes can be accessed.

The first option that will appear is "ACTIVE CODES". By selecting this option, the fault codes that are currently occurring or that have occurred since the last key off cycle will be displayed ( Figure 2.9
).

Press "ENTER". If there are any "Active Codes", the first one will appear on the screen along with a description of the code. If there are any additional codes "Active" the "↑↓" symbol will appear on the screen. Press "↓" key to access additional codes. If there are not any codes "Active", "NO ACTIVE CODES" will appear on the screen.

note.para: Refer to Figure 2.10 for an overview of the MPG Pro-Link electronic service tool.

figure.caption: Figure 2.10- MPG Pro-link Service Tool Overview

svcsubproc.para:
To access "Inactive Codes" press the "FUNC" key. This will access the last prior menu selection. Then press the "↓" key to select "INACTIVE CODES". Press the "ENTER" key ( Figure 2.11
).
Inactive codes are faults that have occurred prior to the last key off cycle and are now stored in memory. An "Active Code" will become an "Inactive" code if the key is shut off.
Record all fault codes that are found. If there are any fault codes found, refer to Electronic Control System Diagnostics, Section 3.5.

note.para: All current fault codes must be repaired and (cleared), before proceeding with further diagnostic testing.

svcsubproc.title: Possible Causes
svcsubproc.para: Electronic Control Module (ECM) detectable faults which will cause a hard or no start condition are:

item.para: Injection Pressure Regulator (IPR) output circuit check fault.
Fuel Demand Command Signal (FDCS) and Cylinder Identification (CI) output circuit check faults.

svcsubproc.title: SUPPLEMENTAL DIAGNOSTICS
svcsubproc.para: If fault codes are set, refer to Electronic Diagnostic form EGED-135-1 and fault code diagnosis.
